summary: This document contains multiple memoranda from staff at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York describing the response to an apparent suicide attempt by inmate Jeffrey Epstein on July 23, 2019. The reports detail finding Epstein with a makeshift noose, rendering aid, and moving him to suicide watch. One report includes Epstein's claim that his cellmate tried to kill him and extort money.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who was found with a homemade orange rope around his neck in his cell, appearing unresponsive. He later claimed his cellmate tried to kill and extort him.

persons.name: Jim Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate who was at the cell door reporting the incident. He was secured and removed from the cell during the response.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Referred to as Epstein's 'Bunkie' whom Epstein accused of trying to kill him and extort money over the preceding week.

persons.name: Officer Silva
persons.context: Officer who grabbed door keys and called for assistance upon responding to the noise from Epstein's cell.

persons.name: S/O
persons.context: Officer who, with another staff member, heard noises and responded to Epstein's cell, observing him with cloth around his neck.

persons.name: Officer J. Masulo
persons.context: Officer observed placing restraints on an individual (likely the cellmate) during the response to Epstein's cell.

persons.name: Lt.
persons.context: Supervisor on scene who requested a stretcher and to whom Epstein's allegations against his cellmate were reported.

persons.name: S.O.
persons.context: Officer who responded to a body alarm, assisted in moving Epstein, and documented Epstein's allegations against his cellmate.

connections.description: Were housed together in cell 124 in the Special Housing Unit. Tartaglione reported the incident to officers.
Epstein alleged that his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been attempting to extort money from him with threats of violence over the preceding week.
Officer Silva was part of the initial response team that secured the cell and called for assistance for Epstein.

events.title: Epstein's Apparent Suicide Attempt
events.description: At approximately 1:27 AM, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell (M Tier, Cell 124) with a homemade orange cloth/rope around his neck, appearing unresponsive. Staff intervened, removed the noose, performed chest compressions, and moved him to a suicide watch unit.

events.title: Epstein's Allegations Against Cellmate
events.description: After becoming responsive on suicide watch, Epstein told an officer that he believed his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, tried to kill him and had been extorting him with threats of violence for a week, claiming he had only told his lawyer.

events.title: Epstein Placed on Suicide Watch
events.description: Following the incident, Epstein was removed from his cell via stretcher, taken to the HA-Unit, dressed in a suicide smock, and placed on formal Suicide Watch observation with staff monitoring.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
Special Housing Unit (9-South), M Tier, Cell 124
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found with a homemade orange noose around his neck in his prison cell on July 23, 2019, at approximately 1:27 AM.

Epstein, after being revived and placed on suicide watch, accused his cellmate, Nicholas Tartaglione, of trying to kill him and of attempting to extort money from him with threats of violence over the preceding week.
Epstein stated he had not reported the threats to correctional staff, only to his lawyer, because he believed staff would not report an assault due to the nature of his charges.

Multiple correctional officers and a lieutenant were involved in the response, which included removing the noose, performing chest compressions, securing the cellmate, and transporting Epstein to a suicide watch unit.
The incident reports are internal government memoranda from the Metropolitan Correctional Center, documenting the official response to the event.
